column3: to his publisher Rayner Unwin ("Dear Rayner")
column4: written while the third volume of ''[[The Lord of the Rings]]''
column6: was in proof and while Tolkien was working on the appendices and maps ("...Silence has meant unremitting labour...")
column7: expressing relief that he approves of the map [i.e. the large-scale map of the area with which ''The Return of the King'' is mostly concerned] ("...It cost me many days labour
column8: plotting it out on squared paper
column9: and researchings into the text...") and asking that his son [[Christopher Tolkien|Christopher]] be given "a suitable fee" for his contribution ("...the draughtsman put my draught into form at a sitting without going to bed until 6 a.m...."); he then discusses proofs
column10: hoping that Rayner has received his main corrections safely "for there were some vital corrections in the set"
column11: as well as later "posthumous" ones which were "due to research into times and distances for the Map"; after noting that he has received no further proofs
column12: he lists the material that he has now sent off
column13: namely "all appendices complete: Copy for missing parts; correction of Galleys for parts of A and B
column14: corrections of Family Trees; and correction of Revises for [[Appendix F]]"; he confesses
column16: that he is not very happy about it
column17: adding that he has been influenced in his choice of material
column19: by letters and "by the comments and requests of more influential critics such as [[W.H. Auden|Auden]] (who came to see me recently) and P.H. Newby" and that he still thinks "it is at once too much and too little" even if if contains "plenty of 'lore' – which Hugh Brogan (son of D.B.)
column20: far the most critical and eagle-eyed of all critics
column21: says is the main attraction"; after further discussing the Appendices (see below)
column22: Tolkien asks if he could have a copy of the revised edition of ''[[The Hobbit]]'' ("...I have not got – and do not think I have ever had – a copy of the ''The Hobbit'' incorporating the revision. Could I have one?...") and throws in another request ("...Is there any hope of getting copies of the American Edition of ''Fellowship''. I have had some of ''Two Towers''..."); in his first postscript
column23: he notes that his last fan letter was from the Vice Chancellor of [[Cambridge]] and that he has also received one from [Sir Peter] Medawar ("...Professor Medawar the physiologist is bullying me – but he says he's afraid there is going to be a 'happy ending'. Would you call it a happy ending?...")
column26: on the whole approves ("...but thinks including (I am relieved to find) the [[Éowyn|Eowyn]]-[[Faramir]] business; but he thinks [[Aragorn]]-[[Arwen]] unnecessary & perfunctory. I hope the fragment of the 'saga' will cure him. I still find it poignant: an allegory of naked hope. I hope you do..."); in the second postscript
column27: he thanks him for sending the bookseller John Wilson of Bumpus's reader's comment; in a third he says he has not had time to go over the accounts for the first two volumes.

column1: This long and complex letter well illustrates the difficulties Tolkien was experiencing in bringing out this last volume
column2: in his perplexity and lack of self-confidence even offering to ditch the whole appendix on translation and pleading for Rayner's advice: "I have I expect in the end kept too much. If anything has to be rejected then please do not let it be the Runes and the Table I have painfully arranged (to fit the space I hope and avoid the sad fate of the [[Tengwar|Feanorian Letters]] which now look very scrappy!). The last two Family Trees Bolger and Boffin I should be glad to jettison. I should also prefer to jettison FII 'on Translation' rather than anything else. I have my doubts about it. Is it really a good thing to exhibit one's working  and is not the simple assumption that Western = English best left alone. What do you think. Does this section contain anything it would be sad to lose? I am still very sorry that the 'facsimiles' of the [[Book of Mazarbul]] are not in. And of course the name lists which would have given me a chance of providing some [[Elvish]] vocabulary. I should be very glad to hear what you really think of all this Appendix matter?"

column1: The first postscript anticipates much about the book's future reputation
column2: in that Tolkien tells Rayner that "among the so-called intelligentsia it is odd that most who bother to write are non-literary and largely scientists"

column1: This letter was sent to the present owner's husband on 26th February 1956 on behalf of Rayner Unwin
column5: ''[[The Letters of J.R.R. Tolkien]]''; presumably no copy was kept and the text was never made available to him. ABPC lists no letters by Tolkien to Rayner Unwin having been offered for sale (apart from one indeterminate reference to a letter addressed to 'Unwin' sold in 1975). The publisher's archives are now at the University of Reading.
